name: sfchronicle
text: State public health officials are asking people to donate blood and, if they’ve recently recovered from COVID-19, blood plasma “to help people who are sick with COVID-19,” @CAPublicHealth said on Twitter. https://t.co/kL5eBwUG8H https://t.co/K7qT963E3g

name: sfchronicle
text: California’s population is growing at the slowest rate in more than a century. https://t.co/1CtdmbSeOu

name: sfchronicle
text:
JUST IN: A crate with 975 coronavirus vaccine vials that was supposed to go to Seton Medical Center in Daly City was held up by state regulators, who had not yet signed off on their delivery to the 357-bed hospital Wednesday. 

https://t.co/y69cPkhFXi

name: sfchronicle
text:
Willie Mays had his 1948 Birmingham Black Barons teammates on his mind Wednesday, especially those who never played in the “major leagues.”

https://t.co/UiOopr6esM

name: sfchronicle
text:
The new stay-at-home order taking effect Thursday across the Bay Area will make camping in the region off-limits for at least the next three weeks.

See which campsites will close temporarily: https://t.co/TUraqkpG1l

name: sfchronicle
text:
Warriors head coach Steve Kerr is leaving open the possibility of starting center James Wiseman in next Tuesday night’s nationally televised season opener at Brooklyn.

https://t.co/dGiKxsTsLB

name: sfchronicle
text:
California’s statewide ICU capacity dropped to 4.1% on Tuesday, with four of its five designated regions below the threshold. 
 https://t.co/9YJjkSn1x9

name: sfchronicle
text:
The delivery of the coronavirus vaccine to California hit its first snags Wednesday when several shipments carrying thousands of vials were delayed by authorities or sent back because of irregularities.

https://t.co/Prdxf9chM4

name: sfchronicle
text: Santa Clara County received its first 5,850 doses of Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine today. https://t.co/UOfqrgv07D

name: sfchronicle
text:
San Francisco crab fishers whose equipment was destroyed by a fire that swept through a Fisherman’s Wharf warehouse in May sued the city’s port for millions of dollars in damages Wednesday.

https://t.co/HwzHF9h3KT

name: sfchronicle
text:
Members of a “crime family” in the East Bay were arrested on suspicion of supplying a stream of illegal drugs to S.F.'s Tenderloin neighborhood.

The bust involved wire taps, undercover agents and a seizure of 10 pounds of fentanyl.

https://t.co/mmgtsDEZDf

name: sfchronicle
text: A coyote bit a grocery store worker in the leg Tuesday night — yet another extremely rare human attack in an East Bay community that has now experienced three incidents since July in a small radius. https://t.co/ZelloOruc6

name: sfchronicle
text: Abraham Lincoln, an iconic American hero, could soon be an outcast in San Francisco, his legacy called into question and his name ripped off a high school, reports @jilltucker. https://t.co/72Qc8uE4r7

name: sfchronicle
text:
JUST IN: California’s new coronavirus cases skyrocketed to more than 50,000 in a day, an astounding figure that is due in part to some backlogged cases in Fresno and L.A. counties being reported.

The previous one-day high was 42,088 cases.

https://t.co/uRJbctcyWK

name: sfchronicle
text:
We're tallying the number of confirmed cases, deaths, hospitalizations and tests reported across the state by day on our Coronavirus Tracker.

https://t.co/53vGYpJtFk

name: sfchronicle
text: Twitter announced it will label and delete misleading tweets about coronavirus vaccines. https://t.co/UOfqrgv07D

name: sfchronicle
text:
Who’s next to get vaccinated? California officials are still figuring it out.  Leading candidates to be next in line are 3.4 million agricultural workers, 1.4 million education and child care workers, and 1.1 million emergency services workers.

https://t.co/GCGCplnXbw

name: sfchronicle
text:
A group of small businesses and national business groups sued California state agencies Wednesday, seeking to rollback broad workplace protections against the coronavirus.

https://t.co/XFKcZB5TVS

name: sfchronicle
text:
The stay-at-home order calls on Bay Area residents to forgo non-essential travel, including vacation trips and tourism.

Here’s what we know so far about how what's allowed and what's not under the new order. 

https://t.co/fBCeQkEeCK

name: sfchronicle
text:
During Labor Day weekend, S.F.-based conductor Sarah Hicks became one of the first musicians in the U.S. to lead an indoor orchestral performance during the pandemic. 

She talks about the experience with @yoshi140: https://t.co/XUwdnQ2NvA

name: sfchronicle
text: “This isn’t the Golden State of the past, which was a place in which we saw people from other states and abroad coming to find their way to the California dream.” https://t.co/POSWSCkIHG

name: sfchronicle
text:
Contra Costa health officials are investigating a coronavirus outbreak that has infected 36 inmates at the Martinez Detention Facility and the West Contra Costa Detention Facility in Richmond.

https://t.co/SG9Ivz0kEy

name: sfchronicle
text:
USCF received its first “limited initial supply” of 975 Pfizer coronavirus vaccine doses, with “several thousand more on the way.” Officials said the first phases of vaccinations are being reserved for UCSF and UCSF Benioff Children’s Hospital staff.

https://t.co/fMj6XpUree

name: sfchronicle
text:
UCSF received its first “limited initial supply” of 975 Pfizer coronavirus vaccine doses, with “several thousand more on the way.” Officials said the first phases of vaccinations are being reserved for UCSF and UCSF Benioff Children’s Hospital staff.

https://t.co/BpYJZCMTsi

name: sfchronicle
text:
Everything about the Giants’ new starting pitcher was analyzed by the data-driven management team and coaching staff, but Farhan Zaidi said the decision-making wasn’t all that complicated.

https://t.co/dkbUWhp1Zj
